text: Bacteriophages are the most abundant biological entity on Earth — estimated 10^31 exist, outnumbering all other organisms combined.
Up to 70% of marine bacteria may be infected by bacteriophages at any given time.
Viruses are the second largest component of biomass in the world's oceans after prokaryotes, with up to 9×10^8 virions per milliliter found in microbial mats.
Phage therapy was used as an alternative to antibiotics in the Soviet Union since the 1920s, decades before Western medicine rediscovered it.
The smallest bacteriophage genomes encode as few as four genes, while the largest contain hundreds of genes.
The largest bacteriophage genomes reach 735 kilobases — larger than some bacterial genomes.
Bacteriophages communicate with each other using a protein called 'arbitrium' to decide whether to kill host cells or remain dormant.
Three Nobel Prizes have been awarded for bacteriophage research — in 1969 for viral replication and in 2018 for phage display technology.
The Hershey-Chase experiment in 1952 used bacteriophages to prove that DNA — not protein — is the genetic material of life.
Some bacteriophages inject their DNA using a hypodermic syringe-like motion, contracting their tail to pierce bacterial cell membranes.
Prions contain no DNA or RNA — they're misfolded proteins that 'reproduce' by corrupting normal proteins into copies of themselves.
All known prion diseases in mammals are 100% fatal with no effective treatment — they progressively destroy brain tissue.
Prions are virtually indestructible — they resist heat, radiation, formaldehyde, and proteases that would destroy any other infectious agent.
Prions can survive heating to 134°C (273°F) for 18 minutes in a pressurized autoclave — conditions that sterilize everything else.
The human incubation period for prion diseases can be 5 to 20+ years, but once symptoms appear, death occurs within months.
Prions may play a role in long-term memory — the same protein-folding mechanism that causes disease might help neurons store information.
Fungal prions exist in yeast and are often beneficial — they help organisms adapt to new environments without changing their DNA.
Prions can persist in soil for years by binding to clay minerals, creating environmental reservoirs of disease.
Plants can uptake prions from contaminated soil and transmit them to animals that eat them — completing an environmental disease cycle.
Mad cow disease (BSE) jumped to humans as variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (vCJD) — one of the few documented prion cross-species transmissions.
Deinococcus radiodurans can survive 6,000 Gy of ionizing radiation — 1,500 times the dose that would kill a human.
Bacteria from Earth survived three years in outer space on the International Space Station, supporting the theory of panspermia.
Viable bacterial spores 40 million years old have been found on Earth — they're hardened against radiation and time itself.
Bacteria have been found living half a mile below Antarctic ice and in the Mariana Trench at crushing pressures of 1,100 bar.
Picrophilus oshimae thrives at pH 0.06 — essentially growing in battery acid, near the theoretical limit for life.
Microorganisms have been found thriving 1.2 km below the seafloor in 120°C sediment — the deepest life discovered.
Endospores from Bacillus bacteria survived heating to 420°C (788°F) — hotter than the surface of Mercury.
Bacteria can survive hypergravity of 403,627 g — conditions only found in cosmic environments like supernova shock waves.
Radiotrophic fungi discovered at Chernobyl actually use radiation as an energy source — essentially 'eating' radioactivity.
Sulfur-breathing bacteria 7,900 feet below Earth's surface eat rocks like pyrite for food and have been isolated from sunlight for millions of years.
Lichen survived 34 days under simulated Mars conditions including UV radiation and extreme cold — suggesting life could exist on Mars.
Bacteria discovered in Antarctica feed on air — using hydrogen and carbon monoxide from the atmosphere for energy.
Bacterial endospores can survive high-velocity impacts up to 299 m/s, suggesting life could travel between planets via meteorites.
Microbes adapt to space in ways 'not observed on Earth' — showing increased growth and virulence in microgravity.
Microbes live in liquid asphalt at Pitch Lake in Trinidad — populations of 10^6 to 10^7 cells per gram thrive in tar.
The human body contains approximately 38 trillion bacterial cells — roughly matching our 30 trillion human cells.
Your microbiome contains 2 million bacterial genes — 100 times more genes than the ~20,000 in the human genome.
500 to 1,000 different bacterial species live in the human gut, belonging to just a few major phyla.
Babies born by C-section have different gut microbiomes than vaginally-born babies — with more pathogenic bacteria like E. coli and Staphylococcus.
Your gut bacteria function like an endocrine organ — producing hormones and signaling molecules that affect your entire body.
Gut bacteria ferment dietary fiber into short-chain fatty acids like butyric acid — essentially producing nutrients you couldn't make yourself.
Probiotics can improve symptoms of anxiety, depression, autism, and OCD when taken in daily doses of 10^9-10^10 bacteria for 1-2 months.
Only about 50% of humans have detectable populations of methane-producing archaea in their guts — colonization is highly variable.
'Obelisks' — a new class of viroid-like elements — were discovered in the human microbiome in 2024, along with their unique proteins called 'oblins'.
Each person's microbiome is unique — like a fingerprint made of bacteria, it varies dramatically between individuals.
Your skin hosts bacteria from 205 different genera across 19 phyla — a miniature ecosystem on your body's surface.
The placenta was long thought sterile, but bacterial DNA has been found there — though contamination during sampling is debated.
Mycorrhizal networks — fungal 'Wood Wide Web' — connect trees underground, allowing them to share nutrients and even send chemical warnings about pests.
Fungal networks can transfer up to 30% of a plant's photosynthetically-fixed carbon to the fungus in exchange for nitrogen and phosphorus.
Trees transfer more carbon to closely related trees via fungal networks — suggesting plants can recognize kin underground.
When a Douglas fir is attacked by insects, it sends chemical signals through fungal networks to neighboring ponderosa pines, which then produce defense enzymes.
Mycorrhizal associations evolved before plants colonized land — they're one of the oldest and most fundamental biological partnerships.
Carbon flows through fungal networks seasonally — shifting to whichever connected plants need it most at different times of year.
Invasive plants can hijack mycorrhizal networks, changing which species the fungi connect to in order to spread allelopathic chemicals to native plants.
Some plants like Monotropa ('ghost pipe') are parasites that steal all their food through mycorrhizal networks — they can't photosynthesize at all.
β-lactamase enzymes that destroy penicillin evolved over 2 billion years ago — bacteria had antibiotic resistance before antibiotics existed.
source_name: PMC - A Brief History of the Antibiotic Era

text: Traces of tetracycline have been found in human bones from ancient Sudanese Nubia dating to 350-550 CE — people were accidentally consuming antibiotics 1,500 years ago.
source_name: PMC - A Brief History of the Antibiotic Era

text: The first hospital-used antibiotic, Pyocyanase (1899), was made from Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteria — decades before penicillin.
source_name: PMC - A Brief History of the Antibiotic Era

text: Each year 25,000 patients in the EU and 63,000 in the US die from infections with multidrug-resistant bacteria.
source_name: PMC - A Brief History of the Antibiotic Era

text: The golden era of antibiotic discovery was the 1950s-1970s — no new antibiotic classes have been discovered since then.
source_name: PMC - A Brief History of the Antibiotic Era

text: Treponema pallidum (syphilis) has remained susceptible to penicillin for 80+ years — one of the few bacteria that hasn't developed resistance.
source_name: PMC - A Brief History of the Antibiotic Era

text: Red soils in Jordan have been used for thousands of years to treat skin infections — they contain antibiotic-producing bacteria that make actinomycin.
source_name: PMC - A Brief History of the Antibiotic Era

text: Paul Ehrlich tested 606 different compounds before finding Salvarsan — the first synthetic antibiotic — showing drug discovery has always been a numbers game.
source_name: PMC - A Brief History of the Antibiotic Era

text: Some bacteria protect their entire colony from antibiotics through 'kin selection' — a small number of resistant bacteria shield their sensitive neighbors.
source_name: PMC - A Brief History of the Antibiotic Era

text: Streptomyces bacteria in soil produce about two-thirds of all naturally-derived antibiotics in clinical use today.
Actinobacteria can be found at depths of more than 2 meters below ground, at densities of 10^6 to 10^9 cells per gram of soil.
Streptomyces accounts for over 95% of Actinomycetales bacteria isolated from soil — they dominate the underground world.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis and M. leprae are likely obligate human parasites — they've co-evolved with humans and can't survive elsewhere.
Tropheryma whipplei, which causes Whipple's disease, has a tiny genome of only 926 kb and G+C content of just 46% — unusually small for bacteria.
Propionibacterium acnes, the bacterium blamed for acne, was recently found inside grapevine plants — transferred horizontally between kingdoms of life.
Salinispora is the first bacterial genus that requires seawater to grow — it's obligately marine.
Nocardia infections are considered an emerging disease — mortality from Nocardia brain abscesses is 31%, three times higher than other brain abscesses.
Corynebacterium glutamicum is an industrial workhorse — used to produce millions of tons of amino acids like glutamic acid and lysine annually.
Bifidobacteria produce antimicrobials and bacteriocins — they actively fight pathogens in your gut while helping you digest food.
Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS) are now one of the major nosocomial pathogens — previously dismissed as harmless skin bacteria.
S. epidermidis accounts for 31% of all nosocomial bloodstream infections — the most common cause of hospital-acquired bacteremia.
S. epidermidis secretes a protease that destroys S. aureus biofilms and prevents nasal colonization — skin bacteria that protect you from worse infections.
The attributable cost per catheter-related bloodstream infection is $11,971 to $56,000 — bacterial biofilms on medical devices are expensive problems.
The SARS-CoV-2 spike protein D614G mutation increased transmissibility — viruses evolve in real-time during pandemics.
The E484K mutation reduces neutralization by antibodies by over 10-fold — a single amino acid change can help viruses escape immunity.
SARS-CoV-2 acquires about 2 mutations per month in the global population — viruses evolve on a timescale we can watch.
~90% of neutralizing antibody activity against SARS-CoV-2 targets the spike receptor-binding domain — a tiny region controls immune recognition.
SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern like B.1.1.7 and B.1.351 emerged independently with similar mutations — convergent evolution under immune pressure.
The N501Y mutation in SARS-CoV-2 increases ACE2 binding affinity — making the virus stick better to human cells.
Mink-to-human transmission of SARS-CoV-2 in Denmark created a novel variant cluster — viruses can ping-pong between species and evolve.
Over 1 million SARS-CoV-2 genome sequences were shared via GISAID — enabling real-time surveillance of viral evolution unprecedented in history.
Prophages (dormant viruses in bacterial DNA) can convert harmless bacteria into deadly pathogens — like making Vibrio cholerae produce cholera toxin.
A 68-year-old patient with an antibiotic-resistant superbug infection was saved in 2017 using personalized phage therapy — cocktails of viruses that kill bacteria.
Some roseophages use deoxyuridine instead of deoxythymidine in their DNA — a way to evade bacterial CRISPR defense systems.
The FDA approved the first phage-based food safety product in 2006 — viruses that kill Listeria bacteria on deli meat.
T4 phage assembly requires helper proteins that act catalytically — viruses have their own molecular machines within machines.
Walter Fiers in 1976 was the first to sequence a complete viral genome — bacteriophage MS2 — launching the era of genomics.
Bacteria have evolved CRISPR, retrons, and Thoeris defense systems against phages — an ancient immune arms race.
The Hailong anti-phage defense triggers bacterial suicide via ion channels — infected cells die to protect the colony.
Phage genomes are highly mosaic — different regions come from completely different evolutionary sources, shuffled by recombination.
Filamentous phages don't kill their hosts — they continuously secrete new virus particles while keeping the bacterium alive.
Some bacteriophages actually protect bacteria from antibiotics by helping form biofilms in cystic fibrosis lungs.
Fatal familial insomnia is a prion disease — patients progressively lose the ability to sleep and die within months.
Kuru — a prion disease spread by ritual cannibalism in Papua New Guinea — had incubation periods of up to 50 years.
Chronic wasting disease in deer and elk is spreading across North America — a prion epidemic in wild ungulates.
Prions create sponge-like holes in brain tissue — the hallmark 'spongiform' damage visible under microscopy.
Multiple system atrophy (MSA) was linked to prion-like alpha-synuclein in 2015 — expanding the prion concept beyond PrP protein.
Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and ALS may spread via prion-like mechanisms — misfolded proteins corrupting normal ones.
Sterilizing surgical instruments against prions requires 1N sodium hydroxide plus autoclaving at 121°C for 30 minutes — far more extreme than standard sterilization.
Prion strains exist with different 'templates' even when made of identical amino acid sequences — misfolding patterns carry information.
Platelets are the largest reservoir of prion protein in human blood — raising concerns about transfusion transmission.
Stanley Prusiner won the 1997 Nobel Prize for discovering prions — initially ridiculed for proposing a protein-only infectious agent.
Thermophilic bacteria thrive above 45°C, while hyperthermophiles require temperatures above 80°C — hotter than any multicellular life can survive.
Pyrolobus fumarii holds the record for high-temperature growth at 113°C (235°F) — above the normal boiling point of water.
Psychrophiles grow best at 15°C or below — some can metabolize at -20°C inside ice.
Halophiles require salt concentrations above 5% to thrive — the Dead Sea and Great Salt Lake are full of them.
Taq polymerase from Thermus aquaticus enables PCR — the enzyme that revolutionized molecular biology came from hot spring bacteria.
Desulforudis audaxviator lives 2.8 km underground in a South African gold mine — completely isolated from all other life for millions of years.
Alkaliphiles live at pH 11 — more basic than household ammonia, in soda lakes where other life dissolves.
Xerophiles survive in the Atacama Desert with ~60% relative humidity — the driest places on Earth still have life.
Polyextremophiles tolerate multiple extremes simultaneously — like the bacterium Thermococcus barophilus that needs both high heat AND high pressure.
Oligotrophs thrive in nutritionally-limited environments — they've evolved to survive on almost nothing.
Ernest Hanbury Hankin in 1896 discovered something in the Ganges River that killed cholera bacteria — the first hint of bacteriophages, 20 years before they were officially discovered.
Félix d'Hérelle named bacteriophages 'bacteria-eaters' from the Greek phagein — and immediately recognized their therapeutic potential in 1917.
Phages were used to treat Red Army soldiers in World War II — Soviet military medicine relied on viruses to fight bacterial infections.
Coliphages serve as indicators of fecal contamination in water — where you find E. coli phages, you find sewage.
A cyanophage discovered in 1977 uses 2-aminoadenine (Z) instead of adenine (A) in its DNA — an alien genetic alphabet.
Phage display technology won the 2018 Nobel Prize in Chemistry — using viruses to evolve new antibodies and drugs.
Bacteria in cheese sometimes get infected by phages, ruining fermentation — cheesemakers battle viruses they can't see.
Temperate phages can give antibiotic resistance genes to their bacterial hosts — viruses spreading drug resistance.
The Luria-Delbrück experiment (1943) used phages to prove that bacterial mutations occur randomly — confirming Darwin over Lamarck for microbes.
Membrane vesicles can transfer viral genomes between different archaeal species — horizontal gene transfer via microscopic bubbles.
Airway cilia beat 10-20 times per second, moving mucus at ~5.5 mm/min — a continuous escalator pushing pathogens out of your lungs.
The adult human lung contains approximately 3 trillion motile cilia — a microscopic forest sweeping the airways clean.
Each ciliated airway cell has over 100 cilia on its surface — more than 100 tiny hairs per cell fighting infection.
Primary ciliary dyskinesia — where cilia don't work properly — causes situs inversus (reversed organs) in 50% of patients.
Cigarette smoke shortens cilia and reduces beat frequency — directly compromising your lungs' bacterial defense system.
ATP released by airway cells stimulates ciliary beating and mucus hydration — your cells chemically signal to clear infections.
Bitter taste receptors on airway cilia detect bacterial compounds and trigger faster beating — your lungs can 'taste' pathogens.
Normal respiratory mucus is ~97% water, ~1% salt, ~1% mucins, and ~1% other proteins — a precisely balanced defense gel.
Cystic fibrosis results from CFTR chloride channel mutations — too little chloride secretion makes mucus too thick for cilia to clear.
Mutations in 33+ genes can cause primary ciliary dyskinesia — the disease can result from broken motors, spokes, or dozens of other ciliary parts.
Phage infection of a single bacterium can produce 100-200 new virus particles within 20-30 minutes.
The T4 bacteriophage DNA injection takes about 30 seconds to transfer all 170,000 base pairs into the host bacterium.
Phages can exist as 'prophages' inside bacterial DNA for countless generations, only activating when conditions deteriorate.
Bacteriophage lambda is the model organism for understanding how viruses 'decide' between lying dormant or killing their host.
The KeyPath test uses bacteriophages to detect MRSA in blood cultures — returning results in 5 hours instead of 2-3 days.
Methanopyrus kandleri holds the record for high-temperature growth in archaea at 122°C (252°F).
The colorful rings of Yellowstone's Grand Prismatic Spring are created by thermophilic bacteria — different species at different temperatures.
Haloquadratum walsbyi is a flat, square-shaped archaeon that floats in hypersaline lakes using gas vesicles.
Dunaliella salina produces beta-carotene commercially in hypersaline lakes — thriving where salt concentration exceeds 20%.
Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans helps remediate mercury contamination in acidic soil — using its merA gene for mercury resistance.
Piezophiles thrive at pressures above 10 MPa (99 atmospheres) — hyperpiezophiles require pressures above 50 MPa.
Osmophiles are adapted to high sugar concentrations — they're why honey doesn't spoil despite containing some microbes.
Capnophiles require high CO2 concentrations — like the bacteria living in ruminant digestive systems.
Some bacteria use lanthanides (rare earth elements) as enzyme cofactors — metals humans consider exotic.
Geobacillus thermodenitrificans can remove heavy metals from industrial effluent in just 12 hours at extreme temperatures.
Tortoises can survive 40,000 roentgens of radiation — 50 times more than the lethal dose for humans.
Lepidopteran insects show significant DNA damage only at 20 Gy or higher — 10 times the dose that damages human cells.
Sulfolobus solfataricus survived Martian-level UV radiation — suggesting microbial life could exist on Mars.
Bacillus boroniphilus is strongly borophilic — thriving in high boron concentrations toxic to most life.
Thermus brockianus from Yellowstone produces a catalase stable at 80°C and pH 10 for 15 days — industrial-strength enzymes from hot springs.
The Human Microbiome Project identified over 10,000 microbial species in 242 healthy volunteers.
The mouth has distinct microbial neighborhoods — bacteria of the same species form different communities on teeth versus tongue.
Lactobacillus species in the vagina produce hydrogen peroxide and lactic acid to suppress pathogens.
African American women have different vaginal flora with less hydrogen peroxide-producing lactobacilli — ethnicity affects microbiomes.
Sexual intercourse with condoms changes lactobacilli levels and increases E. coli in vaginal flora.
The esophagus was thought sterile until the 1980s — it actually has a diverse microbiome dominated by Streptococcus.
The bladder has its own microbiome — standard culture methods just couldn't detect the bacteria present there.
Gut bacteria synthesize vitamin B and vitamin K for you — essential nutrients you get from your microbiome.
Oral bacteria form biofilms that harden into tarite (calculus) if not brushed away — and secrete acids that cause tooth decay.
Trimethylamine produced by gut bacteria gets converted to TMAO in the liver — linked to cardiovascular disease.
Lysozyme in tears has antibacterial activity — it's why eye infections are relatively rare despite constant exposure.
Malassezia yeasts live on skin by consuming oils from sebaceous glands — feeding off your face.
Candida albicans and Lactobacillus mutually inhibit each other — yeast and bacteria battling in your body.
The vaginal microbiome changes throughout the menstrual cycle — fluctuating bacterial communities track hormones.
Methanobrevibacter smithii is the dominant methanogen in human guts — producing methane from hydrogen and CO2.
PrP (prion protein) normally exists on cell membranes of neurons and blood cells — it only becomes dangerous when misfolded.
Normal prion protein (PrPC) binds copper ions — it may have antioxidant functions in healthy cells.
Prion diseases cause characteristic 'astrogliosis' — star-shaped brain cells multiply in response to dying neurons.
Scrapie in sheep was the first prion disease described — named because affected sheep compulsively scrape their wool off on fences.
Sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease affects about 1 in 1 million people annually — prion misfolding occurs spontaneously.
The methionine/methionine genotype at codon 129 of the prion gene increases CJD risk 5-fold compared to heterozygotes.
Feline and exotic ungulate spongiform encephalopathies appeared after contaminated cattle feed spread BSE across species.
Cryo-electron microscopy has revealed the atomic structure of brain-derived infectious prions — finally seeing the enemy.
Prion fibers grow at their ends like crystals — breakage creates more ends, enabling exponential replication.
A drug blocking prion fiber growth could slow disease even without eliminating prions — buying patients more time.
Prion protein is required for bone marrow self-renewal — mice without PrP have impaired blood stem cells.
Autophagy can clear prion aggregates from cells — promoting autophagy delays disease onset in mice.
The keratinase enzyme from Bacillus licheniformis can actually degrade prions — one of few known ways to destroy them biologically.
Sulfa drugs (sulfonamides) are the oldest synthetic antibiotics — discovered in 1935 and still used today.
Antibiotic resistance costs the EU €1.5 billion annually in extra healthcare costs and lost productivity.
Quinolone resistance genes (qnr) were acquired from aquatic bacteria — environmental DNA became clinical resistance.
Artemisinin — the anti-malarial drug from traditional Chinese medicine — was used for thousands of years before modern isolation.
Fleming warned about penicillin resistance in his 1945 Nobel lecture — predicting the crisis before it began.
Penicillinase (β-lactamase) was discovered even before penicillin was widely used — bacteria were pre-adapted to resist it.
Carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) are resistant to nearly all antibiotics — earning the nickname 'nightmare bacteria'.
Agricultural use of antibiotics for growth promotion was banned in the EU in 2006 — reducing environmental resistance pressure.
Sublethal antibiotic concentrations in the environment accelerate resistance evolution through stress responses.
The SOS response in bacteria (triggered by UV and DNA damage) promotes horizontal transfer of resistance genes.
A single fungal network can extend for kilometers underground, connecting thousands of individual trees.
Allelochemicals like juglone from black walnuts travel faster through fungal networks than through soil alone.
Plants connected via fungal networks show primed immune defenses — ready to fight pathogens before they arrive.
Tomato plants connected by mycorrhizal networks upregulate defense genes when a neighbor is infected by fungal pathogens.
Aphid-free plants express salicylic acid pathways only when connected via mycorrhizal network to infested plants.
Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi penetrate plant cell walls; ectomycorrhizal fungi thread between cells — two different strategies.
Carbon moves through fungal networks following source-sink dynamics — flowing from surplus to deficit like water downhill.
Nitrogen flows from nitrogen-fixing plants to non-fixers through mycorrhizal networks — sharing the wealth underground.
Sugar maple saplings receive carbon from the network in spring when budding; trout lilies receive it in fall when developing roots.
A 1% carbon gain through fungal networks can cause a 4-fold increase in seedling establishment — tiny transfers, huge effects.
Bacteria divide so fast that one cell could theoretically produce more mass than Earth in 48 hours — if unlimited resources existed.
The smallest known free-living bacterium is Mycoplasma genitalium with a genome of just 580,000 base pairs.
Pelagibacter ubique is the most abundant organism on Earth — trillions upon trillions live in the ocean.
Bacteria can form multicellular biofilms with internal channels, specialized cell types, and coordinated behaviors.
Quorum sensing allows bacteria to count their population and coordinate behavior — like voting on when to attack.
Bacteria can share antibiotic resistance genes via conjugation — essentially microbial sex spreading drug resistance.
The word 'bacteria' was coined by Christian Gottfried Ehrenberg in 1838 from Greek for 'small stick'.
Magnetotactic bacteria contain chains of magnetic crystals that let them navigate using Earth's magnetic field.
Some bacteria have circular chromosomes; others have linear ones — chromosome shape isn't universal even among prokaryotes.
Endosymbiotic bacteria became mitochondria and chloroplasts — all complex life descended from bacterial mergers.
Wolbachia infects up to 60% of insect species — one of the most successful reproductive parasites in the world.
Bacteria can survive in clouds, traveling thousands of kilometers before raining down to colonize new environments.
Clostridium botulinum produces botulinum toxin — the most acutely lethal substance known, yet used cosmetically as Botox.
Anthrax spores can remain viable in soil for 70+ years — ancient graves can still harbor deadly bacteria.
Vibrio cholerae doesn't cause disease until it colonizes the gut and produces cholera toxin — triggered by environmental signals.
Yersinia pestis (plague) can kill a human in 24-36 hours in its septicemic form — one of history's deadliest pathogens.
Legionella pneumophila lives inside amoebae in water — human infection is accidental, from contaminated cooling towers.
Helicobacter pylori infects half of all humans and causes most stomach ulcers — a discovery that won the 2005 Nobel Prize.
Borrelia burgdorferi (Lyme disease) has one of the most complex genomes of any bacterium — with a linear chromosome and over 20 plasmids.
Rickettsia can only reproduce inside host cells — they're obligate intracellular parasites, like tiny cellular hijackers.
Cyanobacteria were the first organisms to produce oxygen through photosynthesis — changing Earth's atmosphere forever.
Giant viruses (Mimivirus, Pandoravirus) are larger than some bacteria — blurring the line between virus and cell.
Pandoravirus has 2,500 genes — more than some parasitic bacteria and eukaryotes.
Viruses that infect viruses (virophages) exist — parasites have their own parasites.
Retroviruses like HIV insert their DNA into host chromosomes — becoming a permanent part of the infected cell's genome.
About 8% of the human genome consists of ancient retroviral DNA — genetic fossils of ancient infections.
Influenza A virus reassorts its genome segments in pigs and birds — creating new pandemic strains through genetic mixing.
Rabies virus travels along nerves to the brain at about 20-30mm per day — a slow but relentless journey to death.
Smallpox was declared eradicated in 1980 — the only human disease completely eliminated by vaccination.
Polio was 99.9% eradicated but persists in a few countries — close but not complete victory.
Ebola virus kills up to 90% of infected people in some outbreaks — one of the deadliest pathogens known.
Herpesviruses establish lifelong latent infections — once infected, you carry them forever.
Hepatitis B virus has a partially double-stranded DNA genome — unique among human viruses.
Measles is so contagious that 90% of unvaccinated people exposed to it will become infected.
HPV causes virtually all cervical cancers — a virus that causes cancer.
Dengue fever can be worse on second infection — antibodies from the first infection enhance the second.
The honey fungus (Armillaria ostoyae) in Oregon's Blue Mountains covers 2,384 acres — the largest known organism.
Fungi produce powerful antibiotics — penicillin, cephalosporins, and many more came from mold.
Ophiocordyceps fungi turn ants into 'zombies' — hijacking their nervous systems to spread spores.
Cryptococcus neoformans can cause fatal meningitis in immunocompromised patients — thriving in pigeon droppings.
Aspergillus fumigatus releases millions of spores per day — we breathe hundreds of them daily without harm.
Candida auris emerged globally in the 2010s with multidrug resistance — a new fungal superbug.
Histoplasma capsulatum hides inside macrophages — the immune cells meant to kill it become its home.
Fungi are more closely related to animals than to plants — we share a common ancestor with mushrooms.
Dermatophytes (ringworm fungi) evolved to digest keratin — why they attack skin, hair, and nails.
Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has driven over 200 amphibian species to extinction — the worst pathogen in wildlife history.
CRISPR was discovered as a bacterial immune system before becoming a gene-editing tool — bacteria had it first.
Horizontal gene transfer is so common that 'species' is hard to define for bacteria — genes flow freely between lineages.
Archaea were only recognized as a separate domain of life in 1977 — previously lumped with bacteria.
Methanogens produce 1 billion tons of methane annually — microbial farts contributing to climate change.
Thiomargarita namibiensis is visible to the naked eye — the largest known bacterium at 0.75 mm.
Synthetic biology created the first cell with an entirely artificial genome in 2010 — life made from scratch.
Bacterial cell division can occur every 20 minutes under ideal conditions — exponential growth at frightening speed.
The oldest known fossils are microbial stromatolites 3.5 billion years old — life started simple and stayed that way for 3 billion years.
Microbes have been found in every environment tested on Earth — there is nowhere microbes haven't colonized.
Bacterial flagella rotate at up to 1000 rpm — the fastest known biological motor.
Scientists created a minimal cell with only 473 genes in 2016 — the simplest self-replicating life form ever made.
Phage therapy is being revived as 'last resort' treatment for antibiotic-resistant infections in Western hospitals.
E. coli has been engineered to produce insulin since 1978 — the first commercial use of genetic engineering.
Bacteria can be programmed to glow in presence of explosives, arsenic, or disease markers — living biosensors.
Fecal microbiota transplant (FMT) cures Clostridioides difficile infection in over 90% of cases — poop as medicine.
Engineered bacteria can produce biofuels, plastics, and pharmaceuticals — living chemical factories.
Bacteria have been engineered to detect and destroy cancer cells — microbial cancer therapy.
Bioluminescent bacteria light up the ocean at night — creating glowing waves and 'milky seas'.
Photorhabdus luminescens bacteria glow inside nematode worms that invade insect larvae — illuminated parasitism.
Vibrio fischeri in Hawaiian bobtail squid light organs glow to eliminate the squid's shadow from predators below.
Neisseria gonorrhoeae can acquire human DNA during infection — stealing our genes.
Streptococcus mutans produces acid that dissolves tooth enamel — the main cause of dental cavities.
Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common bacterial sexually transmitted infection — often symptomless but damaging.
Treponema pallidum (syphilis) cannot be cultured in the lab — it only grows inside living organisms.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis kills more people than any other single pathogen — 1.5 million deaths annually.
Salmonella can persist on stainless steel surfaces for weeks — why kitchen hygiene matters.
Listeria monocytogenes grows at refrigerator temperatures — cold doesn't stop this food pathogen.
Staphylococcus aureus colonizes the nasal passages of 30% of healthy people — most carriers never get sick.
MRSA (methicillin-resistant S. aureus) evolved in hospitals under antibiotic pressure — a man-made superbug.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa can survive in distilled water and disinfectants — extremely hard to eliminate.
Nitrogen-fixing bacteria convert atmospheric N2 to ammonia — making most life on Earth possible.
Rhizobia bacteria live in root nodules of legumes, providing plants with nitrogen in exchange for sugars.
Anaerobic bacteria at the ocean floor generate hydrogen sulfide — creating toxic 'dead zones'.
Nitrifying bacteria convert ammonia to nitrate in soil — essential for the nitrogen cycle.
Denitrifying bacteria return nitrogen to the atmosphere — completing Earth's nitrogen cycle.
Sulfur-oxidizing bacteria at hydrothermal vents are primary producers — life without sunlight.
Oil-eating bacteria like Alcanivorax help clean up oil spills — natural bioremediation.
Geobacter bacteria can generate electricity by transferring electrons to metal surfaces — microbial fuel cells.
Shewanella bacteria can reduce uranium from soluble U(VI) to insoluble U(IV) — biological nuclear waste cleanup.
Anammox bacteria convert ammonium and nitrite directly to nitrogen gas — discovered only in 1999.
HIV mutates so fast that every possible single-nucleotide mutation occurs daily in an infected person.
Norovirus particles are so infectious that 18 virus particles can cause disease — extreme infectivity.
Rotavirus kills over 200,000 children annually worldwide — mostly in developing countries.
Rhinoviruses (common cold) have over 160 different serotypes — why you can catch colds repeatedly.
Coronaviruses are named for their crown-like spike proteins — 'corona' means crown in Latin.
Zika virus can cross the placenta and cause microcephaly in developing fetuses — a mosquito-borne birth defect.
West Nile virus arrived in New York in 1999 and spread across North America in 5 years — viral invasion in real time.
Hantaviruses are spread by breathing dust contaminated with rodent droppings — inhalation infection.
Nipah virus kills 40-75% of infected people and has no treatment — one of the deadliest known viruses.
Epstein-Barr virus infects 95% of adults worldwide — usually causing only mild illness or none at all.
Saccharomyces cerevisiae (baker's yeast) was the first eukaryote to have its genome sequenced (1996).
Penicillium chrysogenum produces penicillin — Alexander Fleming's 'mold juice' that changed medicine.
Claviceps purpurea (ergot) causes hallucinations when eaten — possibly explaining medieval 'dancing plagues'.
Amanita phalloides (death cap) contains toxins that destroy the liver — responsible for most mushroom deaths.
Pneumocystis jirovecii was a rare infection until HIV — then became the leading cause of AIDS deaths.
Coccidioides immitis spores cause 'Valley fever' — a fungal lung infection endemic to the American Southwest.
Blastomyces dermatitidis can disseminate from lungs to skin, bones, and brain — systemic fungal infection.
Microsporum and Trichophyton cause ringworm, athlete's foot, and jock itch — not worms but fungi.
Sporothrix schenckii is called 'rose gardener's disease' — entering through thorn pricks.
Mucormycosis ('black fungus') surged during COVID-19 in India — opportunistic infection in steroid-treated patients.
Antoni van Leeuwenhoek first saw bacteria in 1676 using a single-lens microscope of his own design.
Louis Pasteur disproved spontaneous generation in 1859 — life only comes from life.
Robert Koch established the germ theory of disease with his famous postulates in 1890.
Ignaz Semmelweis reduced childbirth fever deaths from 10% to 1% with handwashing — ridiculed, later vindicated.
Joseph Lister introduced antiseptic surgery in 1867 — saving countless lives from surgical infections.
The 1918 flu pandemic killed 50-100 million people — more than World War I itself.
The Black Death killed 30-60% of Europe's population in the 1340s — Yersinia pestis on an apocalyptic scale.
Edward Jenner invented vaccination in 1796 using cowpox to prevent smallpox — the first immunization.
John Snow traced a cholera outbreak to a water pump in 1854 — founding epidemiology.
Mary Mallon ('Typhoid Mary') infected 51+ people as an asymptomatic carrier — quarantined for 26 years.
Deinococcus radiodurans repairs its shattered DNA in hours after massive radiation damage — using backup copies.
Some bacteria can survive on electricity alone — 'electric bacteria' living on electrons.
Cable bacteria conduct electricity centimeters through sediments — living electrical wires.
Bacteria can be frozen for 250 million years and revived — trapped in ancient salt crystals.
Nematode-trapping fungi form sticky loops and lassos to catch and digest worms — fungal predators.
Photobacterium profundum lives at crushing pressures of 280 atmospheres in the deep ocean.
Sphingomonas bacteria degrade PAHs (polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons) — eating toxic pollutants.
Ideonella sakaiensis evolved to eat plastic (PET) — discovered in Japanese recycling facility in 2016.
Dehalococcoides bacteria can dechlorinate toxic solvents — bioremediation for industrial pollution.
Acetobacter bacteria turn wine into vinegar — the microbes behind 'mother of vinegar'.
Gut bacteria produce about 95% of the body's serotonin — microbes affecting your mood.
The gut microbiome weighs about 2 kg (4.4 lbs) in an adult — as heavy as your brain.
Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron degrades complex plant polysaccharides — helping you digest vegetables.
Akkermansia muciniphila lives in the gut mucus layer and is associated with metabolic health.
Faecalibacterium prausnitzii produces butyrate and is depleted in Crohn's disease patients.
Breast milk contains prebiotics (HMOs) that specifically feed beneficial gut bacteria in infants.
The appendix may serve as a 'safe house' for gut bacteria to repopulate after diarrheal illness.
Gut bacteria influence blood pressure, body weight, and even risk of colon cancer.
Diet changes can shift gut microbiome composition within 24-48 hours — rapid microbial adaptation.
Exercise increases gut microbiome diversity independently of diet — yet another benefit of activity.
Vancomycin was called 'antibiotic of last resort' until VRSA (vancomycin-resistant S. aureus) emerged.
Colistin is a last-line antibiotic so toxic it was abandoned — now revived for pan-resistant infections.
The mcr-1 gene for colistin resistance was first found in Chinese pig farms in 2015 — agricultural origin.
NDM-1 (New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase) makes bacteria resistant to carbapenems — a global threat.
Extensively drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB) is resistant to at least 4 classes of antibiotics — nearly untreatable.
Antibiotic-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae may soon cause untreatable gonorrhea — 'super gonorrhea'.
Daptomycin was the first new antibiotic class in 30 years when approved in 2003.
Most antibiotic classes came from screening soil Streptomyces — the 'Golden Age' approach is exhausted.
Teixobactin was discovered in 2015 from 'unculturable' soil bacteria using the iChip technology.
Only about 1% of environmental bacteria can be cultured — vast antibiotic potential remains undiscovered.
Halomonas titanicae was found living on the Titanic wreck — slowly eating the ship's iron.
Tersicoccus phoenicis was found only in spacecraft assembly clean rooms — thrives where nothing else can.
Conan the Bacterium' (D. radiodurans) is listed in the Guinness Book of Records as the most radiation-resistant organism.
Bacillus infernus was isolated from 2.7 km underground — one of the deepest bacteria found.
Ferroplasma acidarmanus lives at pH 0 in acid mine drainage — essentially living in battery acid.
Thermus aquaticus from Yellowstone hot springs gave us Taq polymerase — enabling PCR and molecular biology.
Pyrococcus furiosus ('furious fireball') grows fastest at 100°C — boiling water is its comfort zone.
Natronobacterium gregoryi thrives at pH 11.5 in soda lakes — more alkaline than ammonia.
Colwellia psychrerythraea grows at -12°C, the lowest temperature for any known growing organism.
Salinibacter ruber is red due to carotenoids and can survive at 5.2 M salt — saltier than the Dead Sea.
The oldest living culture is a sourdough starter from 1847 San Francisco — continuously fed for 175+ years.
Lactobacillus reuteri produces antimicrobials in the gut and has been in humans for millions of years.
Oenococcus oeni converts malic acid to lactic acid — the malolactic fermentation that softens wine.
Propionibacterium freudenreichii creates the holes in Swiss cheese by producing CO2 bubbles.
Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) produces insecticidal toxins — the basis of organic pesticides and GMO crops.
Nostoc bacteria can fix nitrogen in rice paddies — natural fertilizer from cyanobacteria.
Spirulina (Arthrospira) is sold as a 'superfood' supplement — cyanobacteria you can eat.
Xanthomonas campestris produces xanthan gum — the thickener in salad dressings and ice cream.
Leuconostoc mesenteroides ferments sauerkraut and pickles — preserving vegetables without refrigeration.
Gluconobacter oxydans partially oxidizes glucose to gluconic acid — used industrially for vitamin C production.
Mimicry virus (Mimivirus) was mistaken for a bacterium for years due to its giant size — over 400 nm.
Sputnik virophage infects Mimivirus and reduces its replication — a virus parasite of a virus.
Pithovirus sibericum was revived after 30,000 years frozen in Siberian permafrost — still infectious.
Mollivirus was awakened from 30,000-year-old permafrost in 2015 — ancient giant virus resurrection.
Viruses may have originated from ancient cells that became parasitic — the 'regressive hypothesis'.
Tobacco mosaic virus was the first virus discovered (1898) — crystallized to prove viruses weren't cells.
Porcine circovirus is one of the smallest viruses at 17 nm — barely larger than a ribosome.
Circoviruses have circular single-stranded DNA — the smallest DNA genomes known in viruses.
Polioviruses infect through the intestine but cross into the nervous system — gut infection with neurological consequences.
Adeno-associated virus (AAV) integrates into a specific location on human chromosome 19 — remarkably predictable.
Archaea have cell membranes with ether-linked lipids — fundamentally different from bacterial fatty acid membranes.
Lokiarchaeota was discovered in 2015 and may represent the transition from archaea to eukaryotes.
Asgard archaea have genes for actin and other cytoskeleton proteins — archaeal ancestors of eukaryotes.
LUCA (Last Universal Common Ancestor) lived 3.5-3.8 billion years ago — the ancestor of all life on Earth.
Horizontal gene transfer may have preceded vertical inheritance in early life — genes flowing freely before species existed.
Nanoarchaeota are symbiotic archaea only 400 nm in diameter — among the smallest cells known.
Nanoarchaeum equitans attaches to Ignicoccus cells and lacks genes for most metabolic pathways — dependent on its host.
Thaumarchaea are the most abundant archaea in the ocean — dominating ammonia oxidation.
Candidatus Prometheoarchaeum took 12 years to culture — the closest archaeal relative to eukaryotes.
Sulfolobus species have internal cytoplasm compartments — approaching eukaryotic complexity.
Staphylococcus epidermidis protects skin by producing antimicrobials against pathogens.
Propionibacterium acnes (now Cutibacterium) lives in skin pores and is associated with acne.
Corynebacterium produces the armpit smell — your body odor is bacterial metabolism.
Demodex mites live in human hair follicles and feed on skin cells — you have them in your eyelashes.
Brevibacterium linens gives Limburger cheese its distinctive foot-like smell — same bacteria on feet.
Foot bacteria attract mosquitoes — the more diverse your foot microbiome, the more bites you get.
Bacteria under your arms can hydrolyze testosterone into smelly steroids — different bacteria, different smells.
Oral bacteria form plaque biofilms within hours of brushing — teeth are never truly 'clean'.
Porphyromonas gingivalis linked to gum disease has been found in Alzheimer's brain plaques.
Fusobacterium nucleatum oral bacteria have been found in colorectal tumors — oral microbes gone astray.
Clostridia include both deadly pathogens (C. botulinum, C. tetani) and beneficial gut bacteria.
Clostridium tetani spores are everywhere in soil — any deep wound can cause tetanus without vaccination.
Clostridium perfringens can double in just 10 minutes — one of the fastest-growing bacteria known.
Gas gangrene bacteria produce tissue-destroying enzymes and hydrogen gas — causing crackling under skin.
Clostridioides difficile infection causes nearly 500,000 cases and 29,000 deaths annually in the US.
C. diff spores can survive on hospital surfaces for months — persistent nosocomial threat.
Streptococcus pyogenes ('flesh-eating bacteria') can kill within 24 hours of first symptoms.
Vibrio vulnificus from raw oysters has 50% mortality — deadliest foodborne infection in the US.
Burkholderia cepacia is harmless to most but deadly to cystic fibrosis patients — host-dependent virulence.
Bartonella henselae causes cat scratch disease — bacteria transmitted by cat scratches and flea bites.
Leprosy (Mycobacterium leprae) still affects 200,000 new people annually — not an ancient disease.
M. leprae cannot be cultured in the lab — only in armadillos and mouse foot pads.
Armadillos naturally carry leprosy and can transmit it to humans — a zoonotic reservoir in the Americas.
Tuberculosis bacteria can enter a dormant state for decades — reactivating when immunity wanes.
One-quarter of the world's population has latent TB infection — a massive reservoir of potential disease.
Mycobacterium ulcerans causes Buruli ulcer — the third most common mycobacterial disease after TB and leprosy.
MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex) infection is common in AIDS patients with low CD4 counts.
Nontuberculous mycobacteria are increasing in hot tubs, showerheads, and swimming pools.
Mycobacterium marinum causes 'fish tank granuloma' — infection from aquarium water or fish.
TB treatment requires 6+ months of multiple antibiotics — short-cut courses lead to resistance.
Plasmodium falciparum (malaria) kills over 600,000 people annually — mostly African children.
Trypanosoma brucei causes sleeping sickness by crossing the blood-brain barrier — fatal if untreated.
Trypanosoma cruzi (Chagas disease) infects 6-7 million people in Latin America — often for life.
Toxoplasma gondii infects 30-50% of humans — possibly altering behavior and risk-taking.
Toxoplasma can only sexually reproduce in cats — all other hosts are 'dead ends' for its lifecycle.
Giardia lamblia has two nuclei per cell — giving it a 'face-like' appearance under microscopy.
Cryptosporidium survives chlorination of swimming pools — the leading cause of recreational water illness.
Entamoeba histolytica causes amebic dysentery — the third leading parasitic cause of death worldwide.
Naegleria fowleri is the 'brain-eating amoeba' — 97% fatal infection from warm freshwater.
Acanthamoeba keratitis comes from contaminated contact lens solutions — blindness from protozoa.
Phytoplankton produce 50% of Earth's oxygen — half of every breath comes from ocean microbes.
Prochlorococcus is the smallest and most abundant photosynthetic organism — feeding the base of ocean food webs.
Marine viruses kill 20-40% of ocean bacteria daily — driving nutrient cycling and carbon flux.
Viral shunt returns bacterial carbon to dissolved organic matter — short-circuiting the food chain.
Ocean bacteria contain 3 gigatons of carbon — more than all fish combined.
A single liter of seawater contains 1 billion bacteria and 10 billion viruses.
Synechococcus cyanobacteria produce sticky polysaccharides that aggregate into marine snow.
Coral bleaching occurs when corals expel their symbiotic Symbiodinium algae under heat stress.
Giant kelp forests depend on bacteria to remineralize nutrients in the water column.
Deep ocean bacteria survive for millions of years with almost no energy — metabolic rates near zero.
Bacterial spores have been germinated after 40 million years trapped in amber — extreme longevity.
Bdelloid rotifers have survived 24 million years without sex — incorporating foreign genes horizontally.
Some bacteria can survive millions of years in Antarctic ice — psychrophile extremes.
Zombie bacteria can exist in a viable but non-culturable state (VBNC) — alive but won't grow in lab.
Persister cells are dormant bacteria that survive antibiotics without resistance genes — phenotypic tolerance.
Biofilm bacteria are 10-1000 times more resistant to antibiotics than planktonic cells.
Microbes in biofilms communicate via electrical signals — bacterial 'neural' networks.
Dental biofilms can contain 600+ bacterial species — complex ecosystems in your mouth.
Catheters, implants, and medical devices are common sites for biofilm infections — 80% of chronic infections.
Quorum quenching enzymes can disrupt biofilm formation — a new approach to fighting infection.
The vagal nerve connects gut bacteria to brain function — the gut-brain axis.
Gut bacteria produce neurotransmitters like GABA and dopamine — microbial mood modulation.
Germ-free mice have abnormal brain development and behavior — proving microbiome-brain links.
Autism spectrum disorder is associated with altered gut microbiome composition in many studies.
Depression and anxiety correlate with reduced gut microbiome diversity — psychobiotics are being developed.
Bifidobacterium infantis is critical for infant gut health — evolved specifically for breast-fed babies.
C-section babies have different gut microbiomes than vaginally-delivered babies for years.
Antibiotic use in infancy is linked to increased risk of allergies, asthma, and obesity later.
Hunter-gatherer Hadza people have 40% more gut bacterial diversity than Westerners.
Enterotypes are distinct gut bacterial community types — like blood types for your microbiome.
Bacteriocins are antimicrobial peptides bacteria use to kill competitors — natural antibiotics.
Nisin from Lactococcus lactis is a food preservative used since the 1950s — bacterial antibiotic in your food.
Type VI secretion systems are molecular syringes bacteria use to inject toxins into competitors.
Contact-dependent inhibition lets bacteria inject toxins only into touching cells — close-range warfare.
Myxococcus xanthus hunts in packs and digests prey bacteria — wolves of the microbial world.
Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus is a predatory bacterium that invades and consumes other bacteria from inside.
Vampirococcus attaches to prey bacteria and sucks out their cytoplasm — bacterial vampire.
Micavibrio feeds on the outer surface of other bacteria — grazing rather than hunting.
Some bacteria produce antibiotics only when population density is high enough — quorum-sensing weapons.
Allelopathy in bacteria includes producing antibiotics, siderophores, and volatile compounds to suppress competitors.
Azospirillum promotes plant growth by producing auxins — bacteria as natural fertilizers.
Pseudomonas fluorescens protects plant roots by producing antifungal compounds — biocontrol agents.
Frankia bacteria fix nitrogen in actinorhizal plants like alder — not just legumes have bacterial partners.
Plant immune systems can distinguish beneficial from pathogenic bacteria — selective recognition.
Agrobacterium tumefaciens transfers DNA into plant cells — the basis of plant genetic engineering.
Crown gall disease is caused by Agrobacterium inserting genes that make plant cells produce bacterial food.
Fire blight (Erwinia amylovora) can kill an apple orchard in one season — devastating bacterial disease.
Xylella fastidiosa causes Pierce's disease in grapevines — spread by sharpshooter insects.
Phytoplasmas cause 'witch's broom' disease — turning orderly plants into tangled masses.
Ralstonia solanacearum causes bacterial wilt in over 200 plant species — one of the most destructive pathogens.
Streptomyces produce over 75% of clinically useful antibiotics — the pharmaceutical goldmine of soil bacteria.
The petrichor smell after rain comes partly from geosmin produced by Streptomyces — bacterial aromatherapy.
Actinomycetes form filamentous colonies that look like fungal mycelium — bacteria pretending to be fungi.
Caulobacter crescentus produces the strongest biological adhesive known — stronger than superglue.
Bacterial nanowires can conduct electricity over centimeter distances — living electrical components.
Cyanobacteria created the Great Oxidation Event 2.4 billion years ago — they made our atmosphere breathable.
Some cyanobacteria can perform photosynthesis and nitrogen fixation — but not in the same cell at the same time.
Heterocysts in cyanobacteria are specialized nitrogen-fixing cells that exclude oxygen.
Harmful algal blooms (HABs) produce neurotoxins that can kill fish, birds, and even humans.
Microcystin from cyanobacteria is one of the most powerful liver toxins known — contaminating drinking water.
Beta-lactamase enzymes destroy penicillin-type antibiotics — bacteria's molecular defense against our drugs.
Efflux pumps actively expel antibiotics from bacterial cells — a major mechanism of multidrug resistance.
Riboswitches in bacterial mRNA can sense antibiotics and trigger resistance — RNA-based defense systems.
Integrons can capture and express antibiotic resistance genes — modular genetic resistance platforms.
Plasmids can carry multiple resistance genes — one transfer can make a bacterium resistant to many antibiotics.
R-plasmids (resistance plasmids) were discovered in Japan in the 1950s during Shigella dysentery outbreaks.
Pathogenicity islands are chunks of DNA that convert harmless bacteria into pathogens — transferable virulence.
Transduction by phages can move virulence genes between bacterial species — virus-mediated gene transfer.
Transformation lets bacteria absorb naked DNA from dead cells — recycling genetic information from corpses.
The first whole genome sequence of a free-living organism was Haemophilus influenzae in 1995.
Metagenomic sequencing can identify all microbes in a sample without culturing — sampling the unculturable.
16S rRNA gene sequencing is the 'barcode' for identifying bacteria — universal bacterial fingerprinting.
MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry identifies bacteria in minutes by their protein fingerprint — rapid diagnosis.
Oxford Nanopore sequencing can identify pathogens in real-time — diagnosis at the bedside.
Single-cell sequencing reveals heterogeneity within bacterial populations — not all cells are the same.
